com.autonomy.aci.client.transport.impl

Class HttpClientFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.autonomy.aci.client.transport.impl.HttpClientFactory

  • public class HttpClientFactory
extends Object
    This is a utility class to help create and configure an instance of Apache HttpClient as it appears almost impossible to do so via an IoC container like Spring. This factory assumes that you'll be running in a multi-threaded environment so creates a DefaultHttpClient with an instance of PoolingClientConnectionManager and sets the necessary configuration parameters to the values that have been set via the setter methods.

    Defaults for all the properties that can be configured are:

    maxTotalConnections 20
    maxConnectionsPerRoute 4
    connectionTimeout 7000
    linger -1
    socketBufferSize 8192
    soKeepAlive true
    soReuseAddr true
    soTimeout 10000
    staleCheckingEnabled false
    tcpNoDelay true
    useCompression true

    If you are using something like Spring's IoC container, you can use this class to configure your AciServiceImpl like so: 

       <bean id="httpClientFactory" class="com.autonomy.aci.client.transport.impl.HttpClientFactory"
       p:maxConnectionsPerRoute="20"
       p:maxTotalConnections="120" />

   <!-- Defining this as a stand-alone bean allows it to be shared with the Non ACI API... -->
   <bean id="httpClient" factory-bean="httpClientFactory" factory-method="createInstance" />

   <bean id="aciService" class="com.autonomy.aci.client.services.impl.AciServiceImpl">
     <constructor-arg>
       <bean class="com.autonomy.aci.client.transport.impl.AciHttpClientImpl">
         <constructor-arg ref="httpClient" />
       </bean>
     </constructor-arg>
   </bean>

      • getMaxTotalConnections

        public int getMaxTotalConnections()

      • setMaxTotalConnections

        public void setMaxTotalConnections(int maxTotalConnections)
        Defines the maximum number of connections in total. This limit is interpreted by client connection managers and applies to individual manager instances. The default is 10.
        Parameters:
        maxTotalConnections - The maximum number of connections to set

      • getMaxConnectionsPerRoute

        public int getMaxConnectionsPerRoute()

      • setMaxConnectionsPerRoute

        public void setMaxConnectionsPerRoute(int maxConnectionsPerRoute)
        Defines the maximum number of connections per route. This limit is interpreted by client connection managers and applies to individual manager instances. The default is 4.
        Parameters:
        maxConnectionsPerRoute - The maximum number of connections per route to set

      • getConnectionTimeout

        public int getConnectionTimeout()

      • setConnectionTimeout

        public void setConnectionTimeout(int connectionTimeout)
        Determines the timeout in milliseconds until a connection is established. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. The default is 7000ms (7s).
        Parameters:
        connectionTimeout - The timeout in milliseconds to set

      • getLinger

        public int getLinger()

      • setLinger

        public void setLinger(int linger)
        Sets SO_LINGER with the specified linger time in seconds. The maximum timeout value is platform specific. Value 0 implies that the option is disabled. Value -1 implies that the JRE default is used. The setting only affects the socket close operation. The default is -1.
        Parameters:
        linger - The specified linger time in seconds to set

      • getSocketBufferSize

        public int getSocketBufferSize()

      • setSocketBufferSize

        public void setSocketBufferSize(int socketBufferSize)
        Determines the size of the internal socket buffer used to buffer data while receiving / transmitting HTTP messages. The default is 8192 (8 * 1024).
        Parameters:
        socketBufferSize - The size of the internal socket buffer to use

      • isSoKeepAlive

        public boolean isSoKeepAlive()

      • setSoKeepAlive

        public void setSoKeepAlive(boolean soKeepAlive)
        Defines whether or not TCP is to send automatically a keepalive probe to the peer after an interval of inactivity (no data exchanged in either direction) between this host and the peer. The purpose of this option is to detect if the peer host crashes.
        Parameters:
        soKeepAlive - true to set SO_KEEPALIVE, false otherwise
        Since:
        4.1.2

      • isSoReuseAddr

        public boolean isSoReuseAddr()

      • setSoReuseAddr

        public void setSoReuseAddr(boolean soReuseAddr)
        Defines whether the socket can be bound even though a previous connection is still in a timeout state.
        Parameters:
        soReuseAddr - true to set SO_REUSEADDR, false otherwise.
        Since:
        4.1.2

      • getSoTimeout

        public int getSoTimeout()

      • setSoTimeout

        public void setSoTimeout(int soTimeout)
        Defines the socket timeout (SO_TIMEOUT) in milliseconds, which is the timeout for waiting for data or, put differently, a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets). A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. The default is 10000 (10s).
        Parameters:
        soTimeout - The socket timeout (SO_TIMEOUT) in milliseconds to set

      • isStaleCheckingEnabled

        public boolean isStaleCheckingEnabled()

      • setStaleCheckingEnabled

        public void setStaleCheckingEnabled(boolean staleCheckingEnabled)
        Determines whether stale connection check is to be used. The stale connection check can cause up to 30 millisecond overhead per request and should be used only when appropriate. For performance critical operations this check should be disabled. The default is false.
        Parameters:
        staleCheckingEnabled - true if stale connection checking is to be used, false otherwise

      • isTcpNoDelay

        public boolean isTcpNoDelay()

      • setTcpNoDelay

        public void setTcpNoDelay(boolean tcpNoDelay)
        Determines whether Nagle's algorithm is to be used. The Nagle's algorithm tries to conserve bandwidth by minimizing the number of segments that are sent. When applications wish to decrease network latency and increase performance, they can disable Nagle's algorithm (that is enable TCP_NODELAY). Data will be sent earlier, at the cost of an increase in bandwidth consumption. The default is true.
        Parameters:
        tcpNoDelay - false to use Nagle's algorithm, true to enable TCP_NODELAY

      • isUseCompression

        public boolean isUseCompression()

      • setUseCompression

        public void setUseCompression(boolean useCompression)
        Configures the HttpClient to send the Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate header and thus handle compressed responses from the ACI server.
        Parameters:
        useCompression - true to set the Accept-Encoding header, false to not set it
        Since:
        4.1
